title: Computing Complex Number Operations
description: Compute (3 + 4i)(2 - i) and express in standard form a + bi.
hints: Combine real and imaginary parts separately

title: Complex Division
description: Compute (3 + 4i)/(1 - 2i) and express in standard form.
hints: Multiply numerator and denominator by the conjugate of the denominator

title: Modulus and Argument
description: Find the modulus and argument of z = -1 + i√3.
hints: Argument: θ = arctan(b/a), but be careful about the quadrant
This complex number is in the second quadrant
solution: Modulus: |z| = √((-1)² + (√3)²) = √(1 + 3) = 2. Argument: The point (-1, √3) is in the second quadrant. tan(θ) = √3/(-1) = -√3, so θ = 2π/3 (or 120°).

title: Polar Form Conversion
description: Express z = 1 + i in polar form re^(iθ).
solution: r = √(1² + 1²) = √2. θ = arctan(1/1) = π/4. Therefore z = √2 e^(iπ/4).

title: De Moivre's Theorem
description: Use De Moivre's theorem to compute (1 + i)^6.
hints: First convert 1 + i to polar form
Apply De Moivre's theorem: (re^(iθ))^n = r^n e^(inθ)
Convert back to standard form if needed

title: Finding Complex Roots
description: Find all cube roots of 8.
hints: Use the formula for nth roots: z_k = r^(1/n) e^(i(θ + 2πk)/n) for k = 0, 1, ..., n-1

title: Fourth Roots of Unity
description: Find all fourth roots of unity and plot them in the complex plane.
hints: They form a square on the unit circle
solution: Fourth roots of unity: z_k = e^(iπk/2) for k = 0, 1, 2, 3. z_0 = 1, z_1 = e^(iπ/2) = i, z_2 = e^(iπ) = -1, z_3 = e^(i3π/2) = -i. These form a square with vertices at 1, i, -1, -i on the unit circle.

title: Complex Conjugate Properties
description: Prove that for any complex numbers z and w, the conjugate of their product equals the product of their conjugates: z·w = z̄·w̄.
hints: Let z = a + bi and w = c + di
Then compute its conjugate and compare with z̄·w̄
solution: Let z = a + bi and w = c + di. Then z·w = (ac - bd) + i(ad + bc). So z·w = (ac - bd) - i(ad + bc). Now z̄ = a - bi and w̄ = c - di. Therefore z̄·w̄ = (ac - bd) - i(ad + bc). Thus z·w = z̄·w̄.

title: Open and Closed Sets
description: Determine whether the set S = {z : |z - 1| < 2} is open, closed, or neither in the complex plane.
hints: This set is an open disk centered at 1 with radius 2
Check if boundary points are included (< vs ≤)
An open disk is an open set
solution: S = {z : |z - 1| < 2} is the open disk of radius 2 centered at z = 1. Since the inequality is strict (<), the boundary circle |z - 1| = 2 is not included. Therefore S is an open set (and not closed).

title: Connected Sets
description: Show that the annulus A = {z : 1 < |z| < 2} is a connected domain.
hints: A domain is an open connected set
Then show any two points can be connected by a path in A
solution: The annulus A = {z : 1 < |z| < 2} is open because it can be written as the intersection of the open set {z : |z| < 2} with the complement of the closed set {z : |z| ≤ 1}. To show connectedness, take any two points z_1, z_2 in A. We can connect them by a path that goes along a circular arc at some radius r ∈ (1, 2), then radially to the other point. Since such a path exists for any pair of points, A is connected. Therefore A is a domain.

title: Euler's Formula Application
description: Use Euler's formula e^(iθ) = cos(θ) + i sin(θ) to derive the identity cos(2θ) = cos²(θ) - sin²(θ).
hints: Expand both sides using Euler's formula
solution: e^(i2θ) = cos(2θ) + i sin(2θ). Also, (e^(iθ))² = (cos(θ) + i sin(θ))² = cos²(θ) + 2i cos(θ)sin(θ) - sin²(θ) = (cos²(θ) - sin²(θ)) + i(2sin(θ)cos(θ)). Comparing real parts: cos(2θ) = cos²(θ) - sin²(θ).

title: Complex Exponential
description: Compute e^(π i/2) and express in standard form.
hints: Use Euler's formula: e^(iθ) = cos(θ) + i sin(θ)

title: Stereographic Projection
description: Describe how the point z = i on the complex plane maps to the Riemann sphere under stereographic projection.
hints: Stereographic projection maps from the sphere to the plane
The south pole maps to the origin
Points on the unit circle map to the equator
solution: Under stereographic projection from the north pole, a point z in the complex plane corresponds to a point on the Riemann sphere. For z = i, which has modulus 1, the point lies on the unit circle, so it maps to a point on the equator of the sphere. Specifically, z = i corresponds to the point on the equator in the direction of the positive imaginary axis (y-direction).

title: Triangle Inequality
description: Prove the triangle inequality for complex numbers: |z + w| ≤ |z| + |w|.
hints: Square both sides to avoid absolute values
solution: |z + w|² = (z + w)(z̄ + w̄) = zz̄ + zw̄ + wz̄ + ww̄ = |z|² + |w|² + 2Re(zw̄). Since Re(zw̄) ≤ |zw̄| = |z||w|, we have |z + w|² ≤ |z|² + |w|² + 2|z||w| = (|z| + |w|)². Taking square roots: |z + w| ≤ |z| + |w|.

title: Solving Complex Equations
description: Solve the equation z² + 2z + 2 = 0 in the complex numbers.
solution: Using the quadratic formula: z = (-2 ± √(4 - 8))/2 = (-2 ± √(-4))/2 = (-2 ± 2i)/2 = -1 ± i. The solutions are z = -1 + i and z = -1 - i.

title: Simply Connected Domains
description: Explain why the annulus {z : 1 < |z| < 2} is not simply connected.
hints: A domain is simply connected if every closed curve can be continuously shrunk to a point
Consider a circle around the origin within the annulus
Can this circle be shrunk to a point while staying in the domain?
solution: The annulus A = {z : 1 < |z| < 2} is not simply connected because it contains a "hole" (the region |z| ≤ 1). Consider the circle γ with |z| = 1.5, which lies entirely in A. This circle cannot be continuously shrunk to a point while remaining in A, because shrinking it would require passing through the hole |z| ≤ 1, which is not in A. Therefore A is not simply connected.

title: Function Limit
description: Find lim_{z→i} (z² + 1)/(z - i).
hints: Factor the numerator: z² + 1 = (z - i)(z + i)
solution: z² + 1 = (z - i)(z + i). So (z² + 1)/(z - i) = (z - i)(z + i)/(z - i) = z + i for z ≠ i. Therefore lim_{z→i} (z² + 1)/(z - i) = i + i = 2i.

title: Continuity of Complex Functions
description: Show that f(z) = z² is continuous everywhere in ℂ.
hints: Use the definition: f is continuous at z₀ if lim_{z→z₀} f(z) = f(z₀)
solution: For any z₀ ∈ ℂ, we have |z² - z₀²| = |z - z₀||z + z₀|. As z → z₀, we have |z + z₀| → 2|z₀|, which is bounded. Therefore |z² - z₀²| ≤ C|z - z₀| → 0 as z → z₀. Thus lim_{z→z₀} z² = z₀², so f is continuous at z₀. Since z₀ was arbitrary, f is continuous everywhere.

title: Complex Derivative
description: Use the definition f'(z₀) = lim_{h→0} [f(z₀ + h) - f(z₀)]/h to find the derivative of f(z) = z³.
solution: f'(z₀) = lim_{h→0} [(z₀ + h)³ - z₀³]/h = lim_{h→0} [z₀³ + 3z₀²h + 3z₀h² + h³ - z₀³]/h = lim_{h→0} [3z₀² + 3z₀h + h²] = 3z₀². Therefore f'(z) = 3z².

title: Cauchy-Riemann Equations Verification
description: Verify that f(z) = z² satisfies the Cauchy-Riemann equations. Write z = x + iy and f(z) = u(x,y) + iv(x,y).
hints: Expand z² = (x + iy)² to find u and v
solution: z² = (x + iy)² = x² - y² + 2ixy. So u(x,y) = x² - y² and v(x,y) = 2xy. ∂u/∂x = 2x, ∂v/∂y = 2x, so ∂u/∂x = ∂v/∂y ✓. ∂u/∂y = -2y, ∂v/∂x = 2y, so ∂u/∂y = -∂v/∂x ✓. The Cauchy-Riemann equations are satisfied.

title: Non-Analytic Function
description: Show that f(z) = z̄ (complex conjugate) is nowhere analytic by checking the Cauchy-Riemann equations.
hints: Write z̄ = x - iy, so u(x,y) = x and v(x,y) = -y
Check if C-R equations are satisfied
solution: z̄ = x - iy, so u(x,y) = x and v(x,y) = -y. ∂u/∂x = 1, ∂v/∂y = -1, so ∂u/∂x ≠ ∂v/∂y. The first Cauchy-Riemann equation is not satisfied anywhere. Therefore f(z) = z̄ is nowhere analytic.

title: Finding Where Function is Analytic
description: Determine where f(z) = |z|² is analytic.
solution: |z|² = x² + y², so u(x,y) = x² + y² and v(x,y) = 0. ∂u/∂x = 2x, ∂v/∂y = 0, so we need 2x = 0. ∂u/∂y = 2y, ∂v/∂x = 0, so we need 2y = 0. The Cauchy-Riemann equations are satisfied only when x = y = 0, i.e., at z = 0. Therefore f is analytic only at the origin (and nowhere else differentiable in the complex sense).

title: Harmonic Function Verification
description: Show that u(x,y) = x³ - 3xy² is harmonic by verifying it satisfies Laplace's equation.
solution: u(x,y) = x³ - 3xy². ∂u/∂x = 3x² - 3y², ∂²u/∂x² = 6x. ∂u/∂y = -6xy, ∂²u/∂y² = -6x. Therefore ∂²u/∂x² + ∂²u/∂y² = 6x - 6x = 0. Thus u is harmonic.

title: Finding Harmonic Conjugate
description: Find the harmonic conjugate v(x,y) of u(x,y) = x² - y² to construct an analytic function f(z) = u + iv.
solution: u = x² - y², so ∂u/∂x = 2x and ∂u/∂y = -2y. From C-R: ∂v/∂y = 2x, so v = 2xy + g(x). Also ∂v/∂x = -∂u/∂y = 2y, so ∂v/∂x = 2y + g'(x) = 2y. Thus g'(x) = 0, so g(x) = C. Taking C = 0, we get v = 2xy. Therefore f(z) = x² - y² + 2ixy = (x + iy)² = z².

title: Exponential Function Properties
description: Prove that e^(z+w) = e^z · e^w for all complex z, w.
hints: Write z = x + iy and w = u + iv
Use e^z = e^x(cos y + i sin y)
solution: Let z = x + iy and w = u + iv. Then z + w = (x + u) + i(y + v). e^(z+w) = e^(x+u)[cos(y+v) + i sin(y+v)]. Also e^z · e^w = e^x(cos y + i sin y) · e^u(cos v + i sin v) = e^(x+u)[(cos y cos v - sin y sin v) + i(sin y cos v + cos y sin v)] = e^(x+u)[cos(y+v) + i sin(y+v)] = e^(z+w).

title: Complex Sine Function
description: Compute sin(i) using the definition sin(z) = (e^(iz) - e^(-iz))/(2i).
hints: Substitute z = i into the formula
Simplify e^(i·i) = e^(-1) and e^(-i·i) = e
Note that the result is real

title: Periodicity of Exponential
description: Show that e^z is periodic with period 2πi.
hints: Use e^z = e^x e^(iy) and e^(i(y+2π)) = e^(iy)
solution: For any z = x + iy, we have e^(z+2πi) = e^(x+i(y+2π)) = e^x e^(i(y+2π)) = e^x[cos(y+2π) + i sin(y+2π)] = e^x[cos y + i sin y] = e^z. Since e^(z+2πi) = e^z for all z, the exponential function has period 2πi.

title: Complex Logarithm
description: Find all values of log(i) where log is the complex logarithm.
hints: If log(i) = w, then e^w = i
Write w = u + iv and solve e^u e^(iv) = i
Remember multiple values due to periodicity
solution: We seek w such that e^w = i. Write w = u + iv. Then e^u e^(iv) = i = e^(iπ/2). So e^u = 1 and e^(iv) = e^(iπ/2). From e^u = 1, we get u = 0. From e^(iv) = e^(iπ/2), we get v = π/2 + 2πk for integer k. Therefore log(i) = i(π/2 + 2πk) for k ∈ ℤ. The principal value is Log(i) = iπ/2.

title: Branch Cuts
description: Explain why the complex logarithm requires a branch cut and describe the standard branch cut.
hints: Consider going around the origin in the complex plane
We need to make log single-valued
solution: The complex logarithm log(z) = log|z| + i arg(z) is multi-valued because arg(z) is defined modulo 2π. As we traverse a closed path around the origin, arg(z) changes by 2π, so log(z) changes by 2πi. To make log single-valued, we introduce a branch cut, typically along the negative real axis. The principal branch has -π < arg(z) ≤ π, with the cut preventing continuous passage across the negative real axis.

title: Power Function
description: Compute the principal value of i^i.
hints: Find the principal value Log(i) = iπ/2
solution: Using the principal branch, i^i = e^(i Log i). We found Log(i) = iπ/2. Therefore i^i = e^(i · iπ/2) = e^(-π/2) ≈ 0.2079. Note this is a real number!

title: Entire Functions
description: Prove that any polynomial p(z) is an entire function (analytic everywhere in ℂ).
hints: A polynomial is a finite sum of terms aₙz^n
Use that sums and products of analytic functions are analytic
solution: A polynomial p(z) = a₀ + a₁z + ... + aₙz^n is a finite sum of terms of the form cz^k. Each monomial z^k is analytic everywhere (we can verify this using Cauchy-Riemann equations). Since sums and constant multiples of analytic functions are analytic, p(z) is analytic everywhere in ℂ. Therefore every polynomial is entire.

title: Chain Rule Application
description: Find the derivative of f(z) = e^(z²).
hints: Use the chain rule: (f ∘ g)'(z) = f'(g(z)) · g'(z)
Here f(w) = e^w and g(z) = z²
solution: Let g(z) = z² and f(w) = e^w. Then our function is (f ∘ g)(z) = e^(z²). Using the chain rule: d/dz[e^(z²)] = e^(z²) · d/dz[z²] = e^(z²) · 2z = 2ze^(z²).

title: Line Integral Computation
description: Compute ∫_γ z dz where γ is the line segment from 0 to 1+i.
hints: Parameterize the line: z(t) = t(1+i) for t ∈ [0,1]
solution: Parameterize: z(t) = t(1+i), so dz = (1+i)dt for t ∈ [0,1]. ∫_γ z dz = ∫₀¹ t(1+i)(1+i)dt = (1+i)² ∫₀¹ t dt = (1+2i-1)[t²/2]₀¹ = 2i · 1/2 = i.

title: Contour Integral of Polynomial
description: Evaluate ∫_γ (z² + 3z) dz where γ is the unit circle traversed once counterclockwise.
solution: Since f(z) = z² + 3z is entire, by Cauchy-Goursat theorem, ∫_γ f(z)dz = 0 for any closed contour γ. Alternatively, F(z) = z³/3 + 3z²/2 is an antiderivative, and since γ is closed, ∫_γ f = F(end) - F(start) = 0.

title: Parameterized Circle Integration
description: Compute ∫_{|z|=2} z̄ dz where the circle is traversed counterclockwise.
hints: Find z̄ and dz in terms of θ
solution: z = 2e^(iθ), z̄ = 2e^(-iθ), dz = 2ie^(iθ)dθ. ∫_{|z|=2} z̄ dz = ∫₀^(2π) 2e^(-iθ) · 2ie^(iθ)dθ = 4i∫₀^(2π) dθ = 4i[θ]₀^(2π) = 8πi.

title: ML Inequality Application
description: Use the ML inequality to bound |∫_{|z|=1} e^z/z² dz|.
hints: ML inequality: |∫_γ f| ≤ ML where M = max|f| on γ, L = length of γ
solution: On |z|=1: |e^z| = e^(Re z) ≤ e¹ = e (since Re z ≤ |z| = 1). So |e^z/z²| = |e^z|/|z|² ≤ e/1 = e. Length L = 2π. By ML inequality: |∫_{|z|=1} e^z/z² dz| ≤ e · 2π = 2πe.

title: Independence of Path
description: Show that ∫_γ e^z dz is independent of path by finding an antiderivative.
hints: An antiderivative F satisfies F' = f
If antiderivative exists, integral depends only on endpoints
solution: F(z) = e^z is an antiderivative of f(z) = e^z since d/dz(e^z) = e^z. Therefore, for any path γ from a to b: ∫_γ e^z dz = F(b) - F(a) = e^b - e^a, which depends only on endpoints, not on the path.

title: Cauchy-Goursat Application
description: Evaluate ∫_γ cos(z) dz where γ is any closed contour not enclosing any singularities.
solution: cos(z) is entire (analytic everywhere in ℂ). By the Cauchy-Goursat theorem, for any closed contour γ in the complex plane, ∫_γ cos(z) dz = 0.

title: Integral with Branch Cut
description: Explain why ∫_γ √z dz depends on the path when γ goes around the origin.
hints: √z is multi-valued and requires a branch cut
√z is not analytic on any domain containing the origin
Going around origin changes the branch
solution: The function √z is multi-valued and not analytic on any domain containing the origin. Any branch of √z has a branch cut (typically along the negative real axis or another ray from the origin). When a contour γ crosses the branch cut or encircles the origin, the integral depends on how the branch is traversed. Therefore ∫_γ √z dz is path-dependent when γ goes around the origin.

title: Deformation of Contours
description: Let γ₁ be the circle |z|=1 and γ₂ be the circle |z|=2, both counterclockwise. Show that ∫_{γ₁} f(z)dz = ∫_{γ₂} f(z)dz for f(z) = 1/(z-3).
hints: Both contours don't enclose the singularity
solution: f(z) = 1/(z-3) has a singularity only at z = 3. Since |3| > 2 > 1, the point z = 3 is outside both circles. Therefore f is analytic in the annulus 1 ≤ |z| ≤ 2. By deformation of contours (or Cauchy-Goursat applied to the region between contours): ∫_{γ₁} f dz = ∫_{γ₂} f dz. In fact, both equal 0.

title: Computing with Antiderivative
description: Evaluate ∫_γ sin(z) dz where γ goes from 0 to πi along any path.
hints: Use fundamental theorem of contour integration
solution: An antiderivative of sin(z) is F(z) = -cos(z). Therefore ∫_γ sin(z) dz = F(πi) - F(0) = -cos(πi) - (-cos(0)) = -cos(πi) + cos(0). Using cos(z) = (e^(iz) + e^(-iz))/2: cos(πi) = (e^(-π) + e^π)/2 = cosh(π). So the answer is -cosh(π) + 1 = 1 - cosh(π).

title: Winding Number
description: Compute the winding number n(γ, 0) where γ is the circle |z|=1 traversed twice counterclockwise.
hints: For circle |z|=r traversed once counterclockwise around a, n = 1
Traversing twice doubles the winding number
solution: n(γ,0) = (1/2πi)∫_γ dz/z. For unit circle traversed once, ∫_{|z|=1} dz/z = 2πi. Since γ is traversed twice, ∫_γ dz/z = 2·2πi = 4πi. Therefore n(γ,0) = (1/2πi)·4πi = 2.

title: Integral Along Rectangle
description: Evaluate ∫_γ (2z + 1) dz where γ is the rectangle with vertices at 0, 2, 2+i, i traversed counterclockwise.
hints: Or use antiderivative F(z) = z² + z
solution: Since f(z) = 2z + 1 is entire (analytic everywhere), by Cauchy-Goursat theorem, ∫_γ f(z)dz = 0 for any closed contour γ. Alternatively, F(z) = z² + z is an antiderivative, and since γ is closed: ∫_γ f = F(end) - F(start) = F(0) - F(0) = 0.

title: Contour Integration with Multiple Paths
description: Let γ₁ be the line segment from 0 to 1+i, and γ₂ be the path from 0 to 1 to 1+i (two line segments). Show that ∫_{γ₁} z² dz = ∫_{γ₂} z² dz.
solution: Since f(z) = z² is entire, it has antiderivative F(z) = z³/3 in all of ℂ. Both γ₁ and γ₂ go from 0 to 1+i. Therefore ∫_{γ₁} z² dz = F(1+i) - F(0) = (1+i)³/3 - 0 = (1 + 3i - 3 - i)/3 = (-2 + 2i)/3. Similarly for γ₂. The integrals are equal.

title: Integral of Conjugate Function
description: Show that ∫_γ z̄ dz ≠ 0 for some closed contour γ, proving z̄ is not analytic.
hints: If z̄ were analytic, Cauchy-Goursat would give 0
solution: Let γ be the unit circle traversed counterclockwise. From exercise 3, we found ∫_{|z|=2} z̄ dz = 8πi. For unit circle: z = e^(iθ), z̄ = e^(-iθ), dz = ie^(iθ)dθ. ∫_γ z̄ dz = ∫₀^(2π) e^(-iθ)·ie^(iθ)dθ = i∫₀^(2π) dθ = 2πi ≠ 0. This shows z̄ cannot be analytic (Cauchy-Goursat would require the integral to be 0).

title: Length of Contour
description: Find the length of the contour γ parameterized by z(t) = t + it² for t ∈ [0,1].

title: Maximum Modulus on Contour
description: Find the maximum value of |z²| on the contour |z-1| = 1.
solution: The circle |z-1| = 1 is centered at 1 with radius 1, so it passes through 0 and 2. |z²| = |z|². On this circle, z ranges from points with minimum |z| = 0 (at z = 0) to maximum |z| = 2 (at z = 2). Therefore max|z²| = 2² = 4.

title: Fundamental Theorem Application
description: Use the fundamental theorem of contour integration to evaluate ∫_γ (1/z²) dz where γ goes from 1 to i along any path not passing through 0.
solution: F(z) = -1/z is an antiderivative of f(z) = 1/z² (valid on ℂ\{0}). By the fundamental theorem: ∫_γ (1/z²) dz = F(i) - F(1) = -1/i - (-1/1) = -1/i + 1 = 1 + i (using 1/i = -i).

title: Cauchy Integral Formula Application
description: Use Cauchy's integral formula to evaluate ∫_{|z|=2} (e^z)/(z-1) dz.
solution: By Cauchy's integral formula with f(z) = e^z and a = 1 (which is inside |z|=2): ∫_{|z|=2} (e^z)/(z-1) dz = 2πi·f(1) = 2πi·e^1 = 2πie.

title: Derivative Formula
description: Use Cauchy's formula for derivatives to find f'(0) where f(z) = sin(z).
hints: Cauchy's derivative formula: f'(a) = (1/2πi)∫_γ f(z)/(z-a)² dz
solution: Direct method: f(z) = sin(z), so f'(z) = cos(z). Therefore f'(0) = cos(0) = 1. Alternatively, using Cauchy's formula with a small circle around 0: f'(0) = (1/2πi)∫_{|z|=r} sin(z)/z² dz = cos(0) = 1.

title: Liouville's Theorem Application
description: Use Liouville's theorem to prove that there is no entire function f such that |f(z)| ≤ 1 + |z| for all z ∈ ℂ, unless f is constant.
hints: Liouville: bounded entire functions are constant
This leads to a contradiction unless f is constant
solution: Suppose f is entire with |f(z)| ≤ 1 + |z|. Consider g(z) = f(z)/z for z ≠ 0. For large |z|: |g(z)| = |f(z)|/|z| ≤ (1 + |z|)/|z| = 1/|z| + 1 → 1 as |z| → ∞. So g is bounded for |z| > R for some R. If f(0) = 0 and f'(0) ≠ 0, then g has a simple pole at 0, contradiction. If f(0) = 0 and f'(0) = 0, continue analysis. The rigorous approach: |f(z)| ≤ 1 + |z| means f grows at most linearly, which by generalized Liouville (polynomial growth) implies f is a polynomial of degree ≤ 1. If degree 0, f is constant.

title: Maximum Modulus Principle
description: Let f be analytic on |z| ≤ 1 with |f(z)| ≤ 10 for |z| = 1. Find the maximum value of |f(0)|.
hints: Maximum modulus principle: max occurs on boundary
Use Cauchy's integral formula if needed
solution: By the maximum modulus principle, if f is analytic on and inside |z| ≤ 1, then max_{|z|≤1} |f| occurs on the boundary |z| = 1. Since |f(z)| ≤ 10 for |z| = 1, we have |f(0)| ≤ 10. The maximum value of |f(0)| is 10 (achieved, for example, by f(z) = 10).

title: Fundamental Theorem of Algebra
description: Prove that the polynomial p(z) = z³ + 2z + 5 has exactly 3 roots in ℂ (counting multiplicities).
hints: Fundamental theorem of algebra: degree n polynomial has n roots
solution: The polynomial p(z) = z³ + 2z + 5 has degree 3. By the fundamental theorem of algebra, every polynomial of degree n ≥ 1 has exactly n roots in ℂ when counted with multiplicity. Therefore p(z) has exactly 3 roots (counting multiplicities) in the complex plane.

title: Morera's Theorem
description: Let f be continuous on ℂ with ∫_γ f(z)dz = 0 for all closed contours γ. Prove f is entire using Morera's theorem.
hints: This is exactly the statement of Morera's theorem
Morera is the converse of Cauchy-Goursat
If continuous f has integral 0 over all closed contours, then f is analytic
solution: This is a direct application of Morera's theorem, which states: if f is continuous in a domain D and ∫_γ f(z)dz = 0 for all closed contours γ in D, then f is analytic in D. Since the condition holds for all of ℂ, f is entire (analytic everywhere in ℂ).

title: Higher Derivative Formula
description: Use Cauchy's formula to evaluate ∫_{|z|=1} e^z/z⁴ dz.
hints: Cauchy's nth derivative formula: f^(n)(a) = (n!/2πi)∫_γ f(z)/(z-a)^(n+1) dz
solution: By Cauchy's formula for the nth derivative with n = 3, a = 0, f(z) = e^z: f^(3)(0) = (3!/2πi)∫_{|z|=1} e^z/z⁴ dz. Since f^(3)(z) = e^z (third derivative of e^z is e^z), we have f^(3)(0) = e^0 = 1. Therefore: ∫_{|z|=1} e^z/z⁴ dz = 2πi·f^(3)(0)/3! = 2πi·1/6 = πi/3.

title: Cauchy's Inequality
description: Let f be analytic on |z| ≤ 2 with |f(z)| ≤ 5 for |z| = 2. Use Cauchy's inequality to bound |f'(0)|.
solution: Cauchy's inequality for n = 1: |f'(a)| ≤ M/R where M = max_{|z-a|=R} |f(z)|. With a = 0, R = 2, M = 5: |f'(0)| ≤ 5/2 = 2.5.

title: Mean Value Property
description: Let f(z) = z² and let C be the circle |z| = 2. Verify the mean value property: f(0) = (1/2π)∫₀^(2π) f(2e^(iθ))dθ.
hints: Mean value property: f(a) equals average of f on circle around a
solution: f(0) = 0² = 0. On the circle: f(2e^(iθ)) = (2e^(iθ))² = 4e^(i2θ). (1/2π)∫₀^(2π) 4e^(i2θ)dθ = (4/2π)[e^(i2θ)/(i2)]₀^(2π) = (2/πi)[e^(i4π) - e^0]/(2) = (1/πi)[1 - 1] = 0. Thus f(0) = 0 equals the average, verifying the mean value property.

title: Non-constant Analytic Function
description: Use the maximum modulus principle to prove that if f is analytic and non-constant on a connected domain D, then |f| has no local maximum in D.
hints: Suppose |f| has local maximum at a ∈ D
Maximum modulus principle says this is impossible unless f is constant
solution: Suppose f is analytic and non-constant on connected domain D, and |f| has a local maximum at a ∈ D. Then there exists r > 0 such that |f(z)| ≤ |f(a)| for all z with |z-a| < r. By the maximum modulus principle applied to the disk |z-a| < r, if |f| attains maximum in the interior, then f is constant on that disk. By the identity theorem (analytic continuation), f would be constant on all of D, contradicting our assumption. Therefore |f| cannot have a local maximum in D.

title: Cauchy Estimate Application
description: Suppose f is entire with |f(z)| ≤ e^(|z|²) for all z. Prove that f is a polynomial of degree at most 2.
hints: Use Cauchy's inequality on circles of radius R
solution: On |z| = R: |f(z)| ≤ e^(R²), so M_R = e^(R²). By Cauchy's inequality: |f^(n)(0)| ≤ n!e^(R²)/R^n. For n ≥ 3, as R → ∞: e^(R²)/R^n → ∞ if this bound is to be valid. But we need f^(n)(0) to be finite. More carefully: if n ≥ 3, choose R large enough that R^n grows faster than e^(R²) is false. Actually R^n grows slower than e^(R²). The correct analysis: for n ≥ 3, the bound gives |f^(n)(0)| ≤ n!e^(R²)/R^n → 0 as R → ∞ only fails. We need more refined argument using growth rates. The result follows from Hadamard's theorem: f has at most polynomial growth of order 2, so f is polynomial of degree ≤ 2.

title: Computing with Cauchy Formula
description: Evaluate ∫_{|z-i|=1} z²/(z-i) dz.
solution: By Cauchy's integral formula with f(z) = z² and a = i: ∫_{|z-i|=1} z²/(z-i) dz = 2πi·f(i) = 2πi·i² = 2πi·(-1) = -2πi.

title: Multiple Singularities
description: Evaluate ∫_{|z|=3} 1/[(z-1)(z-2)] dz using Cauchy's formula.
hints: Apply Cauchy's formula to each term
solution: Partial fractions: 1/[(z-1)(z-2)] = 1/(z-1) - 1/(z-2). Therefore ∫_{|z|=3} 1/[(z-1)(z-2)] dz = ∫_{|z|=3} [1/(z-1) - 1/(z-2)] dz. Using Cauchy: ∫ f(z)/(z-a) dz = 2πif(a). First term with f=1, a=1: 2πi(1). Second term with f=1, a=2: 2πi(1). Result: 2πi - 2πi = 0.

title: Minimum Modulus Principle
description: State and prove the minimum modulus principle for non-vanishing analytic functions.
hints: If f is analytic, non-zero on domain D, consider 1/f
solution: Minimum Modulus Principle: Let f be analytic and non-zero on a bounded domain D and continuous on its closure. Then |f| attains its minimum on the boundary of D. Proof: Since f is non-zero on D, g = 1/f is analytic on D. By maximum modulus principle, |g| attains maximum on ∂D. At a point where |g| is maximum, |f| = 1/|g| is minimum. Therefore |f| attains its minimum on the boundary.

title: Schwarz Lemma Application
description: State the Schwarz lemma and use it to prove that if f maps the unit disk to itself with f(0) = 0, then |f(z)| ≤ |z|.
hints: Schwarz lemma: if f analytic on |z| < 1, f(0) = 0, |f(z)| ≤ 1, then |f(z)| ≤ |z|
solution: Schwarz Lemma: If f is analytic on |z| < 1 with f(0) = 0 and |f(z)| ≤ 1 for all |z| < 1, then |f(z)| ≤ |z| for all |z| < 1, and |f'(0)| ≤ 1. Proof: Since f(0) = 0, f(z)/z is analytic (removable singularity at 0). Let g(z) = f(z)/z. On |z| = r < 1: |g(z)| = |f(z)|/|z| ≤ 1/r. Letting r → 1: |g(z)| ≤ 1 on |z| < 1. Therefore |f(z)| = |z||g(z)| ≤ |z|.

title: Derivative Computation via Formula
description: If f(z) = 1/(1-z) for |z| < 1, use Cauchy's formula to find f^(n)(0).
hints: Or use the geometric series: 1/(1-z) = Σz^n
solution: Using series: f(z) = 1/(1-z) = Σ_{k=0}^∞ z^k for |z| < 1. This is the Taylor series around 0: f(z) = Σ_{k=0}^∞ (f^(k)(0)/k!)z^k. Comparing coefficients of z^n: f^(n)(0)/n! = 1, so f^(n)(0) = n!. Alternatively, differentiate f(z) = 1/(1-z) n times using the chain rule to get f^(n)(z) = n!/(1-z)^(n+1), so f^(n)(0) = n!.

title: Radius of Convergence
description: Find the radius of convergence of the power series Σ(z^n)/n².
hints: Use the ratio test or root test
solution: Using root test: |aₙ|^(1/n) = (1/n²)^(1/n) = 1/n^(2/n) → 1 as n → ∞. Therefore R = 1/1 = 1.

title: Taylor Series Expansion
description: Find the first 4 terms of the Taylor series for f(z) = e^(z²) around z = 0.

title: Laurent Series in Annulus
description: Find Laurent series for f(z) = 1/(z(z-1)) in 1 < |z| < ∞.

title: Classifying Singularities
description: Classify singularity of f(z) = (1 - cos z)/z² at z = 0.
solution: 1 - cos z = z²/2 - z⁴/24 + ... So f(z) = 1/2 - z²/24 + ... Removable singularity.

title: Order of Pole
description: Find order of pole of f(z) = z/(z²+1)² at z = i.
solution: (z²+1)² = (z-i)²(z+i)², so f has pole of order 2 at z = i.

title: Essential Singularity
description: Show f(z) = e^(1/z) has essential singularity at z = 0.
solution: e^(1/z) = 1 + 1/z + 1/(2!z²) + ... has infinitely many negative powers, so essential singularity.

title: Simple Zero
description: If f(z₀) = 0 and f'(z₀) ≠ 0, show z₀ is simple zero.
solution: f(z) = a₁(z-z₀) + a₂(z-z₀)² + ... = (z-z₀)g(z) where g(z₀) ≠ 0. Simple zero.

title: Laurent Uniqueness
description: Explain why Laurent series in annulus is unique.
solution: Laurent coefficients uniquely determined by contour integrals.

title: Analytic Continuation
description: Explain analytic continuation of Σz^n to 1/(1-z).
solution: Σz^n = 1/(1-z) for |z| < 1. Function 1/(1-z) extends series beyond radius of convergence.

title: Boundary Convergence
description: Does Σz^n/n converge on |z| = 1?
solution: At z = 1: diverges. At z = -1: converges. Depends on point.

title: Taylor Coefficients
description: Find Taylor series for 1/(1-z)² around z = 0.

title: Multiple Laurent Regions
description: Find Laurent series for 1/[z(z-2)] in 0 < |z| < 2 and |z| > 2.
solution: For 0 < |z| < 2: -1/(2z) - Σz^n/2^(n+1). For |z| > 2: different expansion.

title: Identity Theorem
description: If f(1/n) = g(1/n) for all n and 0 ∈ D, prove f = g.
solution: Points with limit point 0. By identity theorem, f = g on connected D.

title: Series Multiplication
description: Find power series for f(z)g(z) given their series.
solution: Coefficient of z^n is Σ_{k=0}^n aₖbₙ₋ₖ (Cauchy product).

title: Removable Singularity
description: If lim (z-a)f(z) = 0, prove removable singularity.
solution: Limit condition forces a₋₁ = 0. All negative coefficients zero. Removable.

title: Radius from Singularities
description: Why is R = 1 for 1/(z²-3z+2) around z = 0?
solution: Poles at z = 1, 2. Nearest to 0 is at distance 1. So R = 1.

title: Computing Residue at Simple Pole
description: Find the residue of f(z) = z/(z²-1) at z = 1.

title: Residue Theorem Application
description: Evaluate ∫_{|z|=2} 1/(z²-1) dz using residue theorem.
solution: Poles at z = ±1, both inside. Res(f,1) = 1/2, Res(f,-1) = -1/2. ∫ = 2πi(1/2 - 1/2) = 0.

title: Residue at Higher Order Pole
description: Find residue of f(z) = 1/(z-1)³ at z = 1.
hints: Pole of order n: Res = (1/(n-1)!)·lim d^(n-1)/dz^(n-1)[(z-a)^n f(z)]
solution: For n=3 pole: Res = (1/2!)·lim d²/dz²[(z-1)³·1/(z-1)³] = (1/2)·lim d²/dz²[1] = 0.

title: Real Integral via Residues
description: Evaluate ∫_{-∞}^∞ dx/(x²+1) using residue theorem.
hints: Use semicircle contour in upper half-plane
solution: f(z) = 1/(z²+1) = 1/[(z-i)(z+i)]. Pole at z=i in upper half. Res(f,i) = 1/(2i). ∫_{-∞}^∞ = 2πi·(1/2i) = π.

title: Trigonometric Integral
description: Evaluate ∫_0^{2π} dθ/(2+cos θ) using residue theorem.
solution: z = e^{iθ}, dz = ize^{iθ}dθ, dθ = dz/(iz). cos θ = (z+z^{-1})/2. Integral becomes ∫_{|z|=1} 1/(iz(2+(z+z^{-1})/2)) dz. Simplify and find residues. Answer: 2π/√3.

title: Residue from Laurent Series
description: Find residue of f(z) = e^z/z² at z = 0 using Laurent series.

title: Jordan's Lemma
description: State Jordan's lemma and explain its use in evaluating improper integrals.
solution: Jordan's Lemma: If f(z) → 0 uniformly on semicircular arc as R → ∞, then ∫_{C_R} f(z)e^{iaz}dz → 0 for a > 0. Allows evaluating ∫_{-∞}^∞ f(x)e^{iax}dx by closing contour with semicircle.

title: Residue at Infinity
description: Find residue of f(z) = 1/z² at infinity.
solution: g(w) = -w^{-2}·1/(1/w)² = -w^{-2}·w² = -1. No negative powers, so Res(g,0) = 0. Thus Res(f,∞) = 0.

title: Argument Principle
description: State the argument principle and relate it to zeros and poles.
hints: N = zeros, P = poles inside γ
solution: Argument Principle: If f is meromorphic on and inside γ, then (1/2πi)∫_γ f'/f dz = N - P, where N is number of zeros and P is number of poles (counted with multiplicity) inside γ.

title: Rouché's Theorem
description: Use Rouché's theorem to show z^5 + 3z + 1 has 5 roots in |z| < 2.
hints: Rouché: if |f-g| < |f| + |g| on γ, then f and g have same number of zeros
solution: Let f(z) = z^5, g(z) = 3z+1. On |z|=2: |z^5| = 32, |3z+1| ≤ 6+1 = 7 < 32. By Rouché, z^5+3z+1 has same number of zeros as z^5 in |z|<2, which is 5.

title: Principal Value Integral
description: Explain principal value P.V.∫_{-∞}^∞ sin x/x dx and evaluate using residues.
hints: Use contour with small indent at origin
solution: sin x/x is even. Consider ∫_{-∞}^∞ e^{ix}/x dx. Use semicircular contour with small indent at 0. e^{iz}/z entire except at 0. Contribution from large semicircle → 0 by Jordan. Small semicircle gives -πi. Result: π. So ∫ sin x/x dx = π.

title: Residue with Branch Cut
description: Evaluate ∫_0^∞ x^{-1/2}/(1+x) dx using keyhole contour.
hints: Branch cut along positive real axis
Relate top and bottom of cut
solution: Use keyhole contour around [0,∞). z^{-1/2} has branch cut. On top: arg z = 0. On bottom: arg z = 2π. Ratio of integrals: (e^{-iπ/2}-e^{iπ/2}). Pole at z=-1 with residue calculation. Result: π.

title: Series Summation via Residues
description: Use residues to evaluate Σ_{n=-∞}^∞ 1/(n²+1).
hints: Residues at poles of cot and of 1/(z²+1)
solution: π cot(πz) has simple poles at integers with residue 1. Sum of residues of π cot(πz)/(z²+1) at integers = Σ 1/(n²+1). Also compute residues at z=±i. Residue theorem: sum = π coth(π)/1.

title: Logarithmic Residue
description: Find residue of f'/f where f(z) = (z-1)²(z+2).
hints: f'/f has simple poles at zeros of f
Residue at zero of order m is m
solution: f' = 2(z-1)(z+2) + (z-1)² = (z-1)[2(z+2) + (z-1)]. f'/f has poles at z=1 (order 2) and z=-2 (order 1). Res(f'/f, 1) = 2, Res(f'/f, -2) = 1.

title: Fresnel Integral
description: Evaluate ∫_0^∞ cos(x²) dx using complex contour integration.
hints: Use wedge contour: [0,R], arc, [R,0] along angle π/4
solution: Use wedge contour with angle π/4. e^{iz²} entire. On angled segment, z = re^{iπ/4}, z² = r²e^{iπ/2} = ir². ∫ e^{-r²} along ray. Relates to Gaussian ∫ e^{-t²} = √π/2. Result: √(π/8).

title: Mittag-Leffler Expansion
description: Explain how residue theory relates to partial fraction expansions.
hints: Meromorphic function as sum of principal parts
solution: Mittag-Leffler: meromorphic function can be represented as sum over principal parts at its poles plus entire function. Partial fractions are special case. Residues determine coefficients.

title: Conformal Mapping Basics
description: Show that f(z) = z² is conformal except at z = 0.
solution: f'(z) = 2z. This is zero only at z = 0. Therefore f is conformal everywhere except at the origin.

title: Möbius Transformation Properties
description: Show that w = (z-1)/(z+1) maps the unit circle to the imaginary axis.
solution: For |z| = 1: z = e^{iθ}. w = (e^{iθ}-1)/(e^{iθ}+1). Multiply by conjugate: w = (e^{iθ}-1)(e^{-iθ}+1)/|e^{iθ}+1|² = (1+e^{-iθ}-e^{iθ}-1)/|e^{iθ}+1|² = -2i sin θ/(2+2cos θ) = -i tan(θ/2). Purely imaginary.

title: Inversion Mapping
description: Describe how w = 1/z maps circles and lines.
hints: Lines through origin map to lines
Lines not through origin map to circles
Circles through origin map to lines
Circles not through origin map to circles
solution: w = 1/z: (1) Lines through 0 → lines through 0. (2) Lines not through 0 → circles through 0. (3) Circles through 0 → lines not through 0. (4) Circles not through 0 → circles not through 0.

title: Exponential Map
description: Show that w = e^z maps vertical lines to circles and horizontal lines to rays.
solution: z = x+iy, w = e^x e^{iy}. Vertical line x = c: |w| = e^c (circle of radius e^c). Horizontal line y = c: arg w = c (ray at angle c from origin).

title: Joukowski Transform
description: The Joukowski transform w = z + 1/z maps the unit circle to what?
hints: Set z = e^{iθ} on unit circle
solution: For z = e^{iθ}: w = e^{iθ} + e^{-iθ} = 2cos θ. As θ varies from 0 to 2π, w traces the line segment [-2, 2] twice (real axis).

title: Cross-Ratio
description: Define the cross-ratio and explain its invariance under Möbius transformations.
solution: Cross-ratio: (z₁,z₂;z₃,z₄) = [(z₁-z₃)(z₂-z₄)]/[(z₁-z₄)(z₂-z₃)]. Möbius transformations preserve cross-ratios: if w = T(z), then (w₁,w₂;w₃,w₄) = (z₁,z₂;z₃,z₄). Used to find Möbius map sending 3 points to 3 points.

title: Riemann Mapping Theorem
description: State the Riemann Mapping Theorem and give its significance.
solution: Riemann Mapping Theorem: Any simply connected domain D ⊂ ℂ with D ≠ ℂ can be conformally mapped to the unit disk. The map is unique up to Möbius transformations of the disk. Significance: classifies all simply connected domains.

title: Schwarz-Christoffel Formula
description: Explain the Schwarz-Christoffel formula for mapping upper half-plane to polygon.
hints: Maps ℍ to polygon with vertices
solution: Schwarz-Christoffel: f(z) = A∫(z-x₁)^{-α₁}(z-x₂)^{-α₂}...(z-xₙ)^{-αₙ} dz + B maps upper half-plane to polygon with interior angles παᵢ at vertices corresponding to real points xᵢ. A, B are constants.

title: Fluid Flow Application
description: Explain how conformal maps model 2D incompressible fluid flow.
hints: φ = velocity potential, ψ = stream function
solution: In 2D incompressible flow: velocity (u,v) has potential φ and stream function ψ. Complex potential Ω = φ+iψ is analytic. Cauchy-Riemann: ∂φ/∂x = ∂ψ/∂y, ∂φ/∂y = -∂ψ/∂x give u = ∂φ/∂x, v = ∂φ/∂y. Conformal maps transform one flow to another.

title: Electrostatics Application
description: How are conformal maps used to solve 2D electrostatics problems?
solution: Electric potential φ satisfies Laplace's equation ∇²φ = 0, so φ is harmonic. Real/imaginary parts of analytic functions are harmonic. Conformal maps preserve harmonicity, transforming boundary value problems in complex domains to simpler domains (like half-plane or disk) where solutions are known.

title: Annulus Mapping
description: Can every annulus be conformally mapped to a standard annulus r < |z| < 1?
hints: Not all annuli are conformally equivalent
solution: No. Two annuli are conformally equivalent iff they have the same modulus (ratio of radii). An annulus R₁ < |z| < R₂ has modulus R₂/R₁. This is a conformal invariant. Annuli with different moduli cannot be conformally mapped to each other.

title: Conformal Automorphisms
description: Find all conformal automorphisms (bijective conformal maps) of the unit disk.
solution: Conformal automorphisms of unit disk: φ(z) = e^{iθ}(z-a)/(1-āz) where |a| < 1 and θ ∈ ℝ. These are exactly the Möbius transformations mapping disk to itself.

title: Mapping Upper Half-Plane to Disk
description: Find a Möbius transformation mapping upper half-plane to unit disk.
hints: Send specific points to specific points
solution: w = (z-i)/(z+i) maps ℍ to unit disk. Check: i → 0, ∞ → 1, 0 → -1. For Im z > 0: |w| < 1 (verify by computation).

title: Angle Preservation
description: Prove that conformal maps preserve angles between curves.
hints: Consider two curves intersecting at z₀
Multiplication by f'(z₀) rotates and scales
solution: Let γ₁, γ₂ be curves intersecting at z₀ with tangent vectors v₁, v₂. Under w = f(z), images have tangents f'(z₀)v₁, f'(z₀)v₂. Since f'(z₀) ≠ 0, multiplication by f'(z₀) is rotation + scaling, preserving angle: arg(f'v₂/f'v₁) = arg(v₂/v₁).

title: Critical Points
description: What happens to conformality at critical points where f'(z) = 0?
solution: At critical point z₀ where f'(z₀) = 0, f is not conformal. If f''(z₀) ≠ 0, near z₀: f(z) ≈ f(z₀) + (1/2)f''(z₀)(z-z₀)². Angles are multiplied by 2 (e.g., f(z) = z² at origin doubles angles).

title: Dirichlet Problem
description: Explain how conformal mapping solves the Dirichlet problem.
hints: Dirichlet: find harmonic u with given boundary values
solution: Dirichlet problem: find harmonic u in domain D with u = g on ∂D. If f: D → D' conformally, and u' solves Dirichlet in D', then u = u' ∘ f solves it in D (harmonicity preserved). Strategy: map to disk/half-plane where solution is explicit (Poisson integral), then pull back.
